I am not a bio-chemist so I don't understand the constraints of the problem, but why not direct chemical synthesis, which has way more scalability than using biological organisms to do the job? I understand that most protein synthesis is extremely complicated, especially when it comes to crazy polymers like these, but even when we use bacteria, hamster cells, etc to synthesize biochemicals (like insulin for example), we are dealing with a lot of extra biochem processes that aren't directly applicable to the synthesis of what we want to make, and therefore takes a big efficiency hit.

Perhaps we should allocate resources to fully understanding the chemical process then developing tech that can efficiently replicate what the spider does using a minimum process set that is as scalable as we can make it instead of just throwing genes from one organism to another and hoping for the best.

"There have been several efforts in the past to produce garments from Nephila silk although none commercially viable.[39] These include two bed hangings that were shown at the 1900 Paris Exhibition.[40] In 2004 a textile designer, Simon Peers, and an entrepreneur, Nicholas Godley managed in three years work and using 1.2 million Golden silk orb-weavers (collected in the wild and released some 30 minutes later after they produced the silk) to produce a shawl that was as exhibited at the American Museum of Natural History in 2009.[41][42] By 2012 they managed to produce a second, bigger garment, a cape, that, together with the shawl, were exhibited at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.[43]
Another possible use of Nephila silk lies in tissue engineering. A study from the Medizinische Hochschule Hannover reports that processed Nephila silk is an excellent scaffold material thanks to its biocompatibility, mechanical strengths, and its property to promote cell adhesion and proliferation.[44] In particular, the silk acts as a suitable guiding material for peripheral nerve regrowth.[45]

Fishermen on coasts of the indopacific ocean remove Nephila webs and form them into a ball, which is thrown into the water. There it unfolds and is used to catch bait fish.[39]"

EDIT 2020 Update: I've now grown actual spider silk. At time of writing, I'm about to grow 5 gallons of the stuff in the next couple days. Here's the update video https://youtu.be/2hf9yN-oBV4

Couple of things. First the idea we don't know enough isn't really accurate and there are growing numbers of groups who've succesfully made silk on par with the natural varieties. It's pretty straight forward "make the proteins longer". Successful groups add linkers to the ends of the silk genes so that once the individual proteins are produced they stick together in a special way that makes the fibers much longer and stronger. Little bit of protein engineering goes a long way if you've got a fiber gene to work with. That said, silk is a weird protein that is very repetitive and who's gene sequence is GC rich. This makes it hard to isolate from spiders and transfer to a new organism.

So most people make their own DNA sequences that are easy to synthesize, who's protein, while having a lot of the same properties can be inferior for a variety of reasons. This is less of a limit of knowledge and more a limit of print capability. We're limited in the patterns the machine can handle. Our synthesis technology can't print this gene, so we have to massively simplify it and keep it short and repetitive to save on cost. But also even if you print the gene, super long proteins are hard to grow in ecoli at a scale that's useful. They literally get filled up like balloons and stop working, but also that repetitive nature drains the cells supplies of alanine and glycine. So yields are awful even if your fiber is amazing. Doesn't matter if it's better than the real thing if your organism produces miligrams per gallon of media. Hence the weird organism choices like goats.

TL:DR use natural silk genes if possible, add linkers to the end, pick a bigger organism than ecoli, then just use special solvents to dissolve and wet spin fibers. Tada you've got silk on par with the real thing if you choose all the right things. And there are some pretty decent guidelines on what to pick as lots of people have made silks of all sorts of varieties.

So it's not that we don't know enough per say. It's more that our technology has some weird and specific limits that makes this a hard problem to physically make happen in a lab. Even if you design a perfect fiber, actually moving the small volumes of liquid around in the right way and having the reactions and organism work as planned is the limiting agent as sometimes bio just wont play along. The spinnertte thing is largely irrelevant and there's half a dozen ways that all work just as well. It's a really weird biochemistry lab problem more than anything. I obviously had to glaze over some stuff, but that's the gist.

For those interested, I'm actually working on producing a yeast that produces spider silk and am documenting and explaining the whole process on my channel. Rather than synthesis I'm attempting to extract the genes from spiders so I can have a more natural fiber with less human/synthesis error in it:

@SciShow, What timing, yesterday I just read an article "Mimicking Spider Silk" (Scientific American Dec 2018 pace 19). It talks about all the cool reasons that Spider Silk is amazing; but, also why it is really tough to make; and, how we might be able to get around the problem.
It turns out that silk-making DNA is composed of long large protein molecules encoded by lengthy repeating DNA sequences which in general (other than spiders), nature really doesn't like.
It seems that one approach that might work is to use shorter sequences then glue them together. This was reported in Sept 2018 in Biomacromolecules. Unfortunately the process is expensive and requires using chemicals that will melt your face off; but, they're working on that.
